required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Fatigability and Physical Performance: Effects of Resistance Training Variables Manipulation
clinical_study.official_title: Fatigability and Physical Performance: Effects of Resistance Training Variables Manipulation

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluate whether resistance training variables modulate the fatigability (power-duration relationship) and physical performance in adults and older adults

detailed_description.textblock: The resistance training variables manipulation is utilized for maximize the results of resistance training. However it is unclear whether the resistance training variables manipulation modulates the fatigability (i.e. power-duration relationship) and whether this explains the improvement on physical performance (i.e. gait speed, sit-to-stand and timed up and go tests).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes in fatigability measure (e.g. baseline and after 12 weeks of intervention)
primary_outcome.description: The fatigability will be evaluate by 60 maximum voluntary isometric contractions (3 s contraction, 2 s rest) in knee extensors at 70 degree.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Changes in physical performance measure (e.g. baseline and after 12 weeks of intervention)
secondary_outcome.description: The physical performance will be evaluate by gait speed tests (e.g. 10m walking at usual and fast pace, 400m walk at usual and fast pace).

other_outcome.time_frame: Changes in body composition (e.g. baseline and after 12 weeks of intervention)
other_outcome.description: The body composition will be evaluate by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA).

other_outcome.time_frame: Changes in muscle strength (e.g. baseline and after 12 weeks of intervention)
other_outcome.description: Muscle strength will be assess in all subjects, by the one-repetition maximum (1-RM) test, for dynamic exercises. The 1-RM is defined as the maximal weight that is lifted with proper body alignment and correct lifting technique.

arm_group.description: In the LL group, postmenopausal women will perform the resistance training with moderate volume (i.e. three sets per exercise performed until or close to failure) and low load (i.e. 30% of 1RM)
In the HL group, postmenopausal women will perform the resistance training with moderate volume (i.e. three sets per exercise performed until or close to failure) and high load (i.e. 80% of 1RM)
In the HVHL group, postmenopausal women will perform the resistance training with high volume (i.e. six sets per exercise performed until or close to failure) and high load (i.e. 80% of 1RM)
In CG, the postmenopausal women group will not perform exercise

intervention.description: In LL, the postmenopausal women will be submitted to 12 weeks of Resistance training with moderate volume (i.e. three sets per exercise) and low load (i.e. 30% of one repetition maximum)
In HL, the postmenopausal women will be submitted to 12 weeks of Resistance training with moderate volume (i.e. three sets per exercise) and high load (i.e. 80% of one repetition maximum)
In HVHL, the postmenopausal women will be submitted to 12 weeks of Resistance training with high volume (i.e. six sets per exercise) and hig load (i.e. 80% of one maximum repetition)
The CG groups do not will performed the exercise.
